Experimental work on benzene oxidation over C, N doped-MnxOy species showed that the oscillation formation and utilization of sub-surface O2 species from the catalyst was the rate-determining factor for activity. The MnxOy species were synthesized using the biosynthesis method. Characterizations from XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, and In-situ DRIFT were employed to study their catalytic properties. The MnxOy@300 catalyst with low activation energy (Ea = 62 kJ/mol) and TOF of 0.035 h−1 showed the best performance. The kinetic and mathematical model was proposed based on the current results, and those from previous works. The Ea, heat of vaporization, and temperature included in the kinetic model, increased its efficiency. The parameters of the kinetic study were regressed and verified by experimental data and the oxidation route was simulated. The kinetic model was extended into a mathematical model to predict which parameters had the most effect on the C6H6 oxidation process. VOCs are threats to the atmosphere, human health, and survival. To solve this problem, Noble-metal-supported catalysts can be used in the direct catalytic abatement of C6H6 to less harmful forms CO2 and H2O. These catalysts can achieve high benzene removal efficiency at a relatively low temperature. However, the main drawbacks of these catalysts include the limited supply, the high price of precious metals, and the identification of suitable green preparation methods. To circumvent these drawbacks, porous transition Manganese Oxides (MnxOy) supports with different crystal phases were reported as great storage for oxygen and efficient in the oxidation/reaction cycles [2,3]. Ramesh et al., showed that the catalytic activity order over different commercial MnxOy employed in the catalyst assisted oxidation of benzene and toluene was Mn3O4> Mn2O3>MnO2 [4]. Besides, Kim et.al, reported that the activity of MnxOy can be increased by treating commercial MnxOy with salts of K, Ca, and Mg [5]. These MnxOy were synthesized using physicochemical means which use environmentally unfriendly substrates, chemical capping agents, and sophisticated equipment. The plant-mediated method (PM) is a green alternative to pure physicochemical methods as it can produce metal nanoparticles (MNPs) at low temperature and pressure without the use of chemical stabilizers. In previous works, the leaf extract from Cinnamomum camphora (C.camphora) was used to produce supported single/multi-metal nanoparticles (NPs) and metal oxides as a catalyst for many chemical reactions such as degradation of organic pollutants,[6] electro-catalysis [7], CO-oxidation [8], and hydrogenation [9]. Moreover, the leaf extract could self-induce various doping levels of both non-metal and metal atoms in the samples [10]. Parts like the roots, rape pollens, leaves, and hairs can induce additional important elements like (C, K, and N, etc.) to aid catalytic reactions [11,12]. For this purpose, we synthesized diverse MnxOy metal oxide catalysts by employing plant leaf extract as both reducing and stabilizing agents, which were then annealed within 300 ∼ 600 ∘ C . The catalysts were employed in the oxidation of C6H6. However, the current work will not be focusing on the catalytic oxidation of benzene using MnxOy species, as it has been dealt with in previous studies [13,14]. Instead, the plant-mediated synthesized MnxOy species were employed as model catalysts to develop a kinetic and mathematical model to predict the catalytic oxidation of benzene. In addition, the critical parameters that affect the C6H6 oxidation process will be elucidated. The C6H6 oxidation process can be described and optimized using kinetic models. Kinetic models can help us to understand the process and predict the benzene oxidation route. Also, it can be expanded into a mathematical model to predict the final results without the need for experiments. While this can save time and money, the model has to include sufficient amounts of determining factors. Unfortunately, the benzene oxidation process is complex and involves many factors. In literature, it was found that most kinetic models are based on Arrhenius law [15] or a modified Arrhenius equation [16]. The Arrhenius equation is used to prove that an equation or reaction obeys the first-order reaction mechanism [17]. The kinetic models based on the Arrhenius equation, use the exponential function and include parameters such as the pre-exponential factor, temperature, the universal gas constant, and activation energy, (for instance as in the work Liu et al.[18] or Shi et al. [19]). Apart from that, a comparison of the activation energies of diverse catalysts demonstrated that low Ea show higher catalytic performance. This makes activation energy the second most important factor involved in this process after the temperature. The next group of kinetic models was based on Van't Hoff law, as presented in Hu et al. and Bedia et al. [15,20]. The present model was based on a modified Arrhenius equation but in opposite to the Van't Hoff law, where adsorption enthalpy is used. The heat of vaporization was used together with the activation energy. (1) k = k 0 e ( − E a RT ) Where, k0 represents the respective pre-exponential factors, Ea is the activation energy [kJ∙mol−1], R is universal gas constants, [J K−1 mol−1], temperature [K−1]. However, to successfully describe the process, as well as the optimization, it is important to construct a highly accurate kinetic model that can effectively predict the benzene oxidation process. Besides, this model should be innovative, and unlike other kinetic models, should include different factors and base on a different function. Such an approach is a challenge but could propose an innovative solution, which can later be very useful and assists in understanding this process better. Besides, the results from the experimental results, as well as from the kinetic model, were used to create the mathematical model. This current work proposes a kinetic and mathematical model based on experimental data to describe the difficult processes, which occur during the C6H6 oxidation to CO2 and H2O as well as the many factors involved in this process. Supported Pd catalyst (Pd/MnxOy) was later investigated to accessed the possibility of expanding the model to other catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods Washed and shredded Cinnamomum camphora (C.camphora) leaves plucked from a C. camphora plant on Xiamen University campus were sieved with a 50 mm sieve mesh and were stored for the experiments. Pd (NO3)2, Mn3O4, MnO2, Manganese (II) sulfate (MnSO4.H2O), and MnO were provided by Sinopharm Reagent Co. Ltd., while Mn2O3 was bought from the reagent company Xiya Chemical Technology Co. Ltd, China. All commercial catalysts were used without further treatment. Deionized (DI) H2O was used throughout the work. 2.2 Synthesis of MnxOy species 2.2.1 Leaf extract from C.camphora and the catalyst synthesis To derive the leaf extract; 1 g of the dried leaves matter was added to 100 mL deionized (DI) H2O and kept at 90 ∘ C in an already heated oil bath at 160 rpm, for 6 h. The aliquot was then separated via a 0.6 μm sieve to acquire the extract; the obtained extract was then kept in a refrigerator and used later. To synthesize the MnxOy, different amounts of the C.camphora leaf extract in the range of 10-40 mL from (1g/100 mL) were injected into 40 mL of 1M, MnSO4.H2O solution in a 200 mL flask to create a mixture. The mixture was then stirred at 90 ∘ C for 4 h and was frozen at -20°C for 24 h. The frozen mixture was then freeze-dried at -40 ∘ C for 48 h to obtain a brown powder. The obtained powder was then immersed in 10 mL of H2O and ethanol mixture and was washed several times. It was subsequently dried at 50 ∘ C and annealed at 300-600 ∘ C for 6 h and finally was grounded into powder using a lab electric grinder. The obtained catalyst was labeled MnxOy@C, where x, y, and C equals Mn and O oxidation state and the annealing temperature respectively. The adsorption-reduction (AR) method was used to prepare the 0.5-Pd/MnxOy catalyst. Typically, 0.5 g of MnxOy@C was first immersed in the measured aqueous mixture solution of (50 mM Pd (NO3)2) after which the C. camphora was introduced into the suspension to produce the Pd NPs. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was acquired on (LEO, Germany) an LEO-1530 Electron Microscope. Selected area (electron) diffraction (SAED), Energy dispersed X-ray (EDX), and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) examinations were collected on an electron microscope (Tecnai F30, FEI; Netherlands) at an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. Diameter estimations of the as-produced catalyst were done with the Sigma-Scan PRO 4 software. XRD investigation of the dried samples was done on X-ray crystallography (Phillips; Netherlands) with an inbuilt Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA). FT-IR measurements were carried out on Nicolet 6700 spectrophotometer (Thermo Nicolet, U.S.A). Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) tests were carried out on a Micromeritics Tristar 3020 system. In-situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) data were acquired on Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer and Chemical analysis using (ICP-OES) was done on VISTA-MPX, Varian; the USA as in our previous reports [21,22]. 2.4 Catalytic Evaluation 2.4.1 Methods The gas-phase probe of the abatement of C6H6 was conducted in a 1 cm diameter continuous fixed-bed reactor by utilizing a reactant containing 1000 ppm C6H6, and 20 % O2/N2 balance under atmospheric pressure. The feed gas was allowed to flow at dissimilar flow rates (17.1 to 93.5 mL•min−1) into the reactor containing 50 mg of the catalyst, equaling an estimated gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) between 20,000 to 120,000 mL•g−1•h−1. The final C6H6 outlet conversion (Bc) was calculated using corresponding GC peaks of a gas chromatograph (GC) having an FID detector and an Al2O3 column. In the case of the supported catalyst, the Pd loadings were controlled at 0.5 wt. %. The Bc was calculated using the formula below. (2) Bc = C a − C b C b × 100 , Where Bc is the final C6H6 outlet conversion, Cb and Ca represent the output and input concentrations of C6H6. The Turn Over Frequency (TOF) was calculated based on the work by Wang et. al., with some modifications using the equation below [23]. (3) TOF = C h B c % n o Ch is the amount of C6H6 that passed through the catalyst in 1 h and no is the number of moles of the active elements in the catalyst. The benzene injection rate was calculated to be 11.25 mol•h−1. For all Manganese oxide species, the conversion rate was chosen for the same temperature (160 ∘ C ). 3.0 Results and discussions 3.1 XRD, SAED, and BET Analysis The preparation route of the MnxOy species is presented in Scheme 1 above. The XRD patterns of the bio-reduced metal oxide catalyst are displayed in Fig. 1 . The XRD patterns of initial as-produced MnxOy annealed at 300 ∘ C and un-annealed MnxOy, which are displayed in Fig. 1 (a) (IV) and Fig. 1 (V), respectively, show patterns that match the pure Mn3O4 crystalline phase (hausmanite, JCPDS No. 18-0803), as shown in Fig. 1 (b). This agrees with the SAED test, as displayed in Fig. 2 (b). However, MnxOy samples that were annealed at 400 and 500 ∘ C show traces of Mn2O3 cubic bixbyite crystalline phase (alpha, JCPDS No. 24-0508), and completely change to Mn2O3 (JCPDS No. 24-0508) at 600 ∘ C with traces of MnO2 crystalline phase (beta). The BET surface areas were 54.8, 38.6, 28.6, and 18.2 m²•g−1 for MnxOy for samples annealed at 300, 400, 500, and 600 ∘ C , respectively. This result trend was due to sintering or agglomeration of the particle sizes that caused a reduction in the pore volume when the temperature was increased from 300 to 600 ∘ C . 3.2 SEM, TEM, STEM, EDX and HRTEM SEM images of MnxOy species annealed at different temperatures are presented in Fig. S1 (a-d), supporting information (SI). The mean particle sizes of the MnxOy were found to increase with annealing temperatures due to particle sintering. The mean particle size for the un-annealed sample was estimated to be 60.3 ± 4 nm. The samples annealed at 300, 400, 500 and 600 ∘ C were 67.3 ± 4, 85.8 ± 3, 89.8 ± 2 nm, and 0.22 ± 0.01 µm, respectively, with MnxOy@500 and @600 demonstrated slight and severe agglomeration, respectively (Fig. S1 (c-d)). It was observed that the as-synthesized MnxOy@300 had a hexagonal-like shape, as displayed in Fig. 2 (a), but transformed to spherical NPs upon annealing above 400 ∘ C . Meanwhile, its corresponding HRTEM (Fig. 2 (b)) shows lattice distances of about 0.33 and 0.24 nm that match the (112) and (211) planes of Mn3O4 respectively. STEM mapping images of Fig. 2 (c-d) show the elemental distribution of Mn and O. 3.3 XPS and DRUV-vis spectra Analysis The XPS analyses showed binding energies of Mn 2p3/2 for Mn3O4, Mn2O3, and MnO2 were 641.1, 642.19, and 642.61 eV, respectively, as displayed in Fig. 3 [5]. The values observed were 640.2, 640.5, 640.7, and 641.1 eV for the samples annealed from 300 to 600 ∘ C . The O1s XPS spectra of MnxOy species were grouped into lattice (OL) oxygen species at 530.0 eV, oxygen vacancies (OV) at 531.28 eV, and chemisorbed or dissociated oxygen (OC) at 532.36 eV, as shown in Fig. 4 [24,25]. The O1s of MnxOy annealed at 300 to 500 ∘ C showed peaks that were shifted to lower binding energies,[5] probably due to interacting with remaining surface organic groups [26]. OV was abundant in the cases of MnxOy@300 and MnxOy@400 in comparison to MnxOy@500 and MnxOy@600. The calculated Ov from the O1s peaks areas were as follows: MnxOy@300, MnxOy@400, MnxOy@500, and MnxOy@600. Ov and OL promote the abatement of VOCs, as tabulated in Table 1 [27,28]. Also, the C1 and N1s spectra of MnxOy@300 and MnxOy@400 are presented in Fig. S2. Four distinct carbon peaks were fitted from the C1s spectra. The unique peak for Sp3/Sp2-hybridized carbon (C=C/C-C) and adventitious carbon was observed at 286.4eV. The peak at 283.8 eV is assigned to Mn-O-C. O=C-C is seen at 286.4 eV. And the peak at 288.3 eV is associated with H-O-C and/ C-O-CO3 [22]. The N1s spectra are deconvoluted into the O-Mn-N peak at 399.3 eV and the molecularly chemisorbed γ-N2 peak at 401.2 eV. The observed diverse levels of C1s and N1s in the as-synthesized samples can enhance the catalytic activity [11,12]. The observed differences in the amount of Mn4+/Mn3+ species, Mn-O-C, and O-Mn-N bonds among the biogenic MnxOy species would narrow their energy gaps. Additionally, it would also promote their low-temperature absorbance, as observed from the DRUV-vis spectra analysis of the biogenic MnxOy@300 and commercial Mn3O4 catalyst in Fig. S3. The pure Mn3O4 shows absorbance below 426 nm and the MnxOy@300 catalyst shows a redshift to higher absorbance, indicating the incorporation of C, N doping as supported by the EDX and XPS analysis [12]. Table S1 shows the estimated values of Mn, O, C, and N from their respective XPS peak areas. 3.4 H2 Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and Kinetic and TOF Studies H2-TPR test was done to study the reducibility of the MnxOy species, as shown in Fig. 5 . The MnxOy@300 catalyst presents four reduction peaks. The peaks are classified into two main reduction peaks. The shoulder peak observed at 50~193 ∘ C is attributed to the first peak of reduction (FRP), and the peak observed in between 365~440 ∘ C is attributed to the second reduction peak (SRP). However, it was found that the peaks were at lower temperatures than those reported in the literature [2]. This was due to C, N self-doping of the catalyst by biomolecules from the leaf extract [26]. In addition, the FRP of MnxOy@400, MnxOy@500 and MnxOy@600 were observed at 293 ∘ C , 349 ∘ C , and 357 ∘ C , respectively, while the SRP of MnxOy@400, MnxOy@500 and MnxOy@600 were observed at 365~440 ∘ C , 498 ∘ C and 646 ∘ C , respectively. The reduction peaks are ascribed to the transformation of Mn4+ to Mn2O ∼ Mn2O3 ∼ Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 ∼ MnO, respectively as the temperature increases. Yongnian et al. reported a spinel-like Mn3O4 catalyst having Mn2+ ions situated in its tetrahedral area while Mn3+ ions are seen in its tetragonally contorted octahedral areas [29]. The non-stoichiometric Mn3O4 possesses non-stoichiometric O2 attached to tetrahedral Mn, forming three types of Mn3+–O bonds. They concluded that the degree of reduction difficulty of diverse Mn3+–O types to MnO are as followed: tetrahedral Mn3+< long octahedral Mn3+~ then short octahedral Mn3+ or long octahedral Mn3+< and finally tetrahedral Mn3+and short octahedral Mn3+. This assumption proposed a two-step reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [29]. In another study, Christel et al. reported that the MnO2 catalyst exhibited two reduction peaks, at about 393 and 625 ∘ C , respectively [30]. Moreover, Li et al., reported that two Mn3O4 species MnOx-1-300 and MnOx-2-500 showed dissimilar TPR profiles, whereby the former showed three and the latter two [2]. These examples suggest that the TPR profile of MnxOy species would depend on their constituent and preparation methods. The observed diverse TPR patterns of the MnxOy species are due to dissimilar contact surface area and size. Extra oxide species are easily reduced at lower temperatures (LTR) when the particle sizes of metal oxides are small in comparison to large ones because of their abundant readily available surface areas. Kinetic studies estimated from four points at conversions below T20 are reported in Fig. S4. Details of the estimate are reported in the supporting information. Their Ea, from lowest to highest, are: MnxOy@300 (62 kJ/mol) > , MnxOy@400 > (87 kJ/mol) > , MnxOy@500 (141 kJ/mol) > and MnxOy@600 (166 kJ/mol). And their TOF results were 0.035, 0.014, 0.007, and 0.0023 h−1 for MnxOy@300, MnxOy@400, MnxOy@500, and MnxOy@600, respectively. 3.5 Catalytic Activity Evaluation 3.5.1 Effect of MnxOy species and GHSV on the Catalytic Activity The C6H6 oxidation activities of the MnxOy species were reported in Fig. 6 (a). MnxOy@300 and MnxOy@400 presented T90 conversion (the temperature at which conversion reaches 90 %) at 218 ± 3.4 and 237 ± 2.3 ∘ C compared to 268 ± 2.6 and 296 ± 1.5 ∘ C for MnxOy@500 and MnxOy@600. Their catalytic performances are correlated to their respective physicochemical properties such as surface areas, size, chemical state, and composition. From the SEM images (Fig. S1), and the H2-TPR results (Fig. 5) it was observed that the MnxOy@300 with smaller size was readily reduced at lower LTR than the other synthesized supports. In this work, the MnxOy@300 with the smallest particle sizes (67.3 ± 4 nm), had its lower reduction peak occur at 193.1, 234 ∘ C and its high-temperature reduction peak (HTR) at 330, 454 ∘ C which is much lower than the other MnxOy species and most reported in the literature [2,3]. Moreover, it is a known fact that Ov in metal oxide catalysts promotes their catalytic performance [27]. In addition, at lower reduction temperatures, catalysts can easily transport their OL [31]. Meanwhile, from the O1s test, the MnxOy@300 catalyst showed the highest Ov and OL, which are corresponding to abundant Mn-O bonds, while MnxOy@600 showed the smallest Ov, which is in good agreement with the above characterizations. The reaction was promoted by the weak Mn–O bonds [32,33]. The catalytic activity of the MnxOy@300 was compared to commercial Mn2O3 and Mn3O4. The commercial catalysts demonstrated a much lower activity due to their inability to effectively generate surface-active Oxygen species. And their surface areas, 4 and 7 m2∙g−1 respectively, limited the absorption/adsorption of benzene, Fig. 6 (b). Also, 0.5-Pd/MnxOy@300 catalyst was also used to probe the effect of GHSV, as displayed in Fig. 6 (c). It was observed that the conversion of benzene to CO2 and H2O was slow at higher GHSV. This is expected due to the increase in C6H6 molecules. However, the effect on the C6H6 conversion was reduced at GHSV > 60,000 mL•g−1•h−1. 3.6 Kinetic model for the benzene oxidation The presented study was carried out based on a newly developed kinetic model that was modified from the Arrhenius equation. A minimum amount of activation energy (Ea) is required for reactants to be transformed into products. In the presented kinetic model, this fundamental principle was used in the sigmoidal function to describe the benzene oxidation process [34]. The data for the kinetic model was obtained from the above examination (MnxOy@300, MnxOy@400, MnxOy@500, MnxOy @600) and others in the literature which were presented in Table S3. The investigated temperature ranged from 10 to 380 ∘ C . The conversion profiles for all data used were similar to the sigmoidal function (Fig. 6) [20,35-37]. Therefore, the sigmoidal function was used, and the tests gave promised results. Additionally, when the temperature was increased, the conversion rate, as well as the amount of oxidized benzene, was increased at a specific time of 20 minutes. Therefore, the whole process was strictly connected to the variable temperature and not to the time. Based on Eq. (9), a relationship between the HV of the catalyst and the activation energy was established. Although this idea is different from the standard Arrhenius equation, upon the first tests were conducted, the results were found to be promising. This could be because the HV is the inherent stability of the bulk metal material by the metal–metal bonding strength. Therefore, when the temperature of the process reaches some point, the catalyst begins to work. This stability is strictly connected with the activation energy, which is different for different materials. A comparison of the model prediction and experimental data are shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 . 3.7 Model evaluation The simulation of the potential concentration route was conducted in MatlabR2018b. It can be observed that the linear regression indicated a good fitting of the model to the used data. The presented kinetic model in this work was based mostly on the temperature, heat of vaporization, and activation energy. This new idea promises innovative research solutions for predicting final results to substitute experimental data. 3.8 The mathematical model for predicting the benzene conversion The kinetic model was further used in the mathematical model as detailed below. Also, the simulation of the benzene conversion was estimated. The temperature during the simulation was controlled by a program in the GC and was increased by 20 ∘ C every 20 minutes. However, since the time range was constant, the model was based on the temperature. The initial amount of oxygen was equal to 2400 ppm and the amount of benzene was equal to 800 ppm. The results are presented below in Fig. 8. As the C6H6 oxidation process is complex, the modeling of this process is not popular. Hence, to the best of our knowledge, no mathematical models are available in the literature as of recent. This is because it is difficult to describe the various stages involved in the C6H6 oxidation process, using mathematical formulas. However, after the kinetic model was prepared and tested, it was observed that the sigmoidal function could be used in the mathematical model to solve this problem. Hence, this kind of solution increased the efficiency of the model and allowed for good prediction, which later helped understand which parameters were important. 3.8.1 Mathematical procedures The first three coefficients were described by using Eqs. (10)–(12). The relation between the space velocity, surface area, and oxygen species was obvious but not very high. For instance, the influence of GHSV from 10,000 to 40,000 mL•g−1•h−1 on the conversion was very high. But when the GHSV was higher, C6H6 conversion was not possible at lower temperatures. Upon in depth analysis, it was obvious from the results of different papers, that after achieving a GHSV value of 60,000 mL•g−1•h−1, its influence on C6H6 conversion becomes minimal. Therefore, the coefficient in the model Eq. (10) for the space velocity is limited by the GHSV value of 40,000 mL•g−1•h−1. In the case of Oads/Oltt, higher values promoted C6H6 conversion and the process starts at a lower temperature as compared to catalyst with lower values. Hence, Eq. (11) was required to calculate the influence of the surface area on the conversion. Thus, a higher surface area promoted the process and C6H6 conversion was achieved faster. The coefficient 3 was created after the first tests were conducted. And it influenced the temperature range in which the process occurs. It was observed that high activation energy delays the C6H6 oxidation process and vice versa. The correctness for this model was conducted for more than fourteen papers which guarantee a wide data range (Supporting information Table S3) like, for instance, from our previous work [38] or Li et al. [39]. The average error for 91 sets of data was found to be less than 10% and the highest average error was 95.6%. For 76 tests, the average error was smaller than 35%, while for 30 tests, the average error was smaller than 20%. These data scatter were connected with diverse data from a dozen papers. Moreover, the experimental methods were not the same in all papers. In the case of the EF results, a value close to 1, shows that the calculated values from the model were in agreement with the values obtained in reality. The result of 0 or negative means that the mean value was a better predictor than the proposed model. From the results in Table 2 , it was observed that the model had a good prediction. The approximation coefficient and validation showed a satisfactory fit of the empirical values and model. The obtained values were all greater than 0.8. Additionally, the model efficiency and second coefficients indicated that the model was a good fit. The coefficient r2 represents the part of the variable explained by the model. Fig. S6 shows a computer program that was written based on the mathematical model to simulate the benzene oxidation process. The computer program contains four sections. The first section “Input data” contains an editable textbox where the user can provide data and press the “Calculate’’ button. The second section contains tables with the results. The third section ‘‘Chart’’ displays a chart of the results. And the final section displays information about the program. 3.10 In-situ DRIFTs of the benzene combustion over the MnxOy@300 catalyst The In-situ DRIFT spectroscopy tests were conducted to study the reaction intermediates and predict the oxidation mechanism. Before each test, N2 was first allowed into the catalyst chamber to remove any adsorbed surface molecules on the catalyst for 20 min at 150 ∘ C . The In-situ DRIFT over the MnxOy@300 catalyst is presented in Fig. S5. The temperature was varied from 40 to 210 ∘ C . Alkoxide groups are seen at 1155, 1077, and 1028 cm−1 and were markedly amplified as the temperature was increased. The peaks at 3035, 3041, and 3062 cm−1 represent the un-detached surface adsorbed benzene.[40] The C=O stretching vibrations of benzoquinone groups at 1629, 1469, and 1338 cm−1 were seen at 40 ∘ C and gradually vanished when the reaction temperature was varied from 40 to 210 ∘ C . Therefore, Benzoquinone groups are believed to be the tentative reaction intermediates. C-H from the CH3 species aromatic ring bonds with active O2− and O− groups from the MnxOy@300 catalyst to form benzoyl intermediate (C6H5-CH2-O) at the catalyst surface. In particular, the characteristic CO2 peaks located at 2340 and 2349 cm−1 and H2O at 3380-3457 are markedly promoted and the C-H stretching vibrations of adsorbed C6H6 and the weak ones at 3062, 3035, and 3041 cm−1 were observed to vanish. 3.11 Proposed oxidation mechanism The mechanisms of the reaction are postulated as follows; molecular O2 was first activated to active oxygen (O−2, O−1) groups via the MnxOy@300 catalyst redox cycle, Schema 2. Then, the MnxOy@300 catalyst absorbed benzene molecules on its surface via rich surface OL, alkoxide groups (C-O-metal), and physisorbed oxygen. Next, C6H5-CH2-O species were produced via the abstractions of hydrogen atoms from the aromatic rings of C6H6 and/or transformation of the phenolate species [41]. The C6H5-CH2-O species were then further oxidized over the MnxOy@300 catalyst in the presence of lattice and physisorbed oxygen and alkoxide species. This enabled enough oxygen vacancies to promote an oscillation redox cycle for the production of CO2 and H2O. The MnxOy@300 catalyst with a rich-valence metal oxide station and easy low-temperature reducibility would facilitate the Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+ redox cycle to produce abundant adsorbed oxygen groups. Moreover, the porous architecture, easily accessible specific surface area, and small crystallite sizes of the MnxOy@300 catalyst were paramount to promote the diffusion of surface lattice oxygen and molecular benzene. This will create several active sites for the excellent benzene abatement reaction of MnxOy@300 over the other tested catalyst. Table S2 compares the C, N doped-MnxOy@300 catalyst with reports in the literature. As observed in Table S2, the catalytic activities of the catalysts, outperformed others from previous literature. However, it should be noted that it was difficult to get similar testing conditions for all the comparisons. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, C6H6 oxidation was studied over biosynthesized MnxOy catalysts and was compared to commercial ones. The C, N doped-MnxOy@300 catalyst presented a T100 of 240 ∘ C at GHSV of 20,000 mL•g−1•h−1 much lower than commercial Mn3O4, Mn2O3, MnO2, and MnO. In-situ DRIFT data showed that C6H5-CH2-O fragments from the disintegration of C6H5OH species and/or the abstractions of H atoms from the aromatic rings of C6H6 were the intermediate species and were later oxidized to CO2 and H2O. More importantly, the experimental data were analyzed and were used with others from the literature to propose a kinetic model based on the modified Arrhenius equation. The various steps in the C6H6 oxidation process over the MnxOy catalyst were described using various kinetic and mathematical expressions with initial assumptions. The models showed that the benzene oxidation process was strongly dependent on the combination of catalyst properties such as activation energy, O2 species, and heat of vaporization. The main factor aside from the catalyst, responsible for the speed of reaction was temperature. Reaction time had no marked effect on the oxidation process. In addition, the effect of GHSV reduced > 60,000 mL•g−1•h−1. The mathematical model was successfully tested for other works in literature with good prediction. Apart from the possibility of estimation of conversion during the C6H6 oxidation, the mathematical model was further applied in the computer program. This computer program can be used by other people interested in this area. The work proposed innovative research solutions for predicting final results to substitute experimental data. coredata.dc:description: Experimental work on benzene oxidation over C, N doped-MnxOy species showed that the oscillation formation and utilization of sub-surface O2 species from the catalyst was the rate-determining factor for activity. The MnxOy species were synthesized using the biosynthesis method. Characterizations from XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, and In-situ DRIFT were employed to study their catalytic properties. The MnxOy@300 catalyst with low activation energy (Ea = 62 kJ/mol) and TOF of 0.035 h−1 showed the best performance. The kinetic and mathematical model was proposed based on the current results, and those from previous works. The Ea, heat of vaporization, and temperature included in the kinetic model, increased its efficiency. The parameters of the kinetic study were regressed and verified by experimental data and the oxidation route was simulated. The kinetic model was extended into a mathematical model to predict which parameters had the most effect on the C6H6 oxidation process.
coredata.dc:title: Biogenic MnxOy as an efficient catalyst in the catalytic abatement of benzene: From kinetic to mathematical modeling
